Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Science coordination office for Summit Station/ISI Observatory and the Greenland Traverse
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Division of Polar Programs has been funding substantial scientific activities at Summit Station, Greenland (72°N 38°W, 3250 meters above sea level), for over twenty years. Summit Station hosts the Greenland Environmental Observatory (GEOSummit), a cooperation between the National Science Foundation (NSF) and the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration with permission from the Danish Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland to provide long-term environmental measurements. Summit is the only high-elevation, free-tropospheric, inland environmental observatory in the Arctic which is manned throughout the year. Summit therefore fills a unique niche in the international scientific community?s global measurement capability. The Science Coordination Office (SCO) for Summit Station and the Greenland Ice Sheet serves in an advisory capacity to NSF?s Arctic Research Support and Logistics Program. SCO?s primary role is to present the needs and desires of the science community working on the Greenland Ice Sheet in discussions and decision making processes involving NSF, its primary logistics support contractor, and other stakeholders. The SCO also works with NSF, NSF?s contractor, and science teams to work out equitable and efficient use of resources, and strives to ensure that the wide range of science and support activities impact the pristine character of Summit as lightly as possible. SCO shares in the long-range goal of redeveloping Summit infrastructure in ways that will reduce long-term operation and maintenance costs, and reduce the emissions of pollutants by facilities on the station and the aircraft and traverse vehicles that visit. The SCO also helps coordinate visits to Summit for educational groups at all levels, from high school to post-graduate.

The SCO will work closely with NSF and all relevant stakeholders in the design of a revitalized Summit Station where reducing operational and maintenance effort (and costs) will preserve the site for future science by reducing emissions. Additional scientific communities, including astronomy and astrophysics, have recently expressed interest in using Summit Station as an Arctic base for new observations. SCO will actively participate in discussions with all interested parties to develop a site plan to accommodate an influx of additional research activities while maintaining long-standing focus on climate-relevant research which requires clean air and snow conditions. SCO?s website is a keystone of communication to the science community, with several new features added over the past few years, including; a Google Earth based GIS recording activity in the region over the past 9 years, a virtual tour using Streetview images, a new Working at Summit section that targets new investigators, a comprehensive bibliography of published work near Summit, and a quarterly Newsletter). SCO will conduct a comprehensive overhaul of the web site to improve navigation, and will continue to add new features.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sitting atop the Greenland Ice Sheet is a collection of structures that have been a base of research for nearly thirty years. The science and discovery that has taken place at Summit, Greenland is impressive and varied. Initially serving as the site for the collection of the GISP-2 ice core that, at the time, provided the most detailed history of the Earth?s atmosphere over the past 100k years the site has substantially evolved. Today, Summit is being investigated as a site to place instruments to peer into the depths of the universe seeking to uncover signals and unravel the intricacies of Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) in synchronicity with other astronomical observatories across the world.

 

To maintain this facility requires a great deal of resources. Not only is funding from the U.S. National Science Foundation and other Agencies working at the site required, but also a dedicated team of professionals to attend the needs of the scientific objectives. Infrastructure is subject to immense challenges due to the extreme weather, high accumulation and drifting of snow, and difficult access. Resources in the form of: i) funding, ii) operational and logistical, iii) planning at multiple levels, iv) strategic development are required to assure the site is developed in an optimal fashion. The Science Coordination Office (SCO) works with federal agencies, scientists, and the logisticians to manage and prioritize these resources.

 

An increasingly important role of the SCO is to coordinate interdisciplinary activities that at times have conflicting requirements. For instance, the site has been used as a test bed for the development of instruments. But some of these tests require power produced from fossil fuel generators. One of the key aspects of Summit is the pristine nature of the site as a climate observatory. Over the years of development efforts have been placed on limiting the growth of fossil power sources in favor of the development of renewable energy sources. Coordinating and limiting energy use is critical to achieve the goal of maintaining Summit in its pristine state.

 

The SCO facilitates the optimal use of resources and helps prioritize with community input and feedback how the site will be developed over the long-term. Each year, new challenges arise. Initially, the emphasis was on maintaining ?clean snow sectors?. However, with the increased interest from the astrophysics community, now there is a need to preserver ?clean frequencies? and not pollute the sensitive radio telescope instrumentation. As new structures are placed, consideration must be take to mitigate any impact they may have on drifting snow so as not to invalidate historical observations of snow height changes that have been used for validation of NASA satellites.

 

An additional role of the SCO has been to coordinate and foster international representation and participation. Summit is a cornerstone location of Greenland research, providing an essential logistical hub for some deep field activities. The Greenland Traverse has historically delivered resources and created fuel caches for deep some of the international ice coring projects conducted at NEEM and now East GRIP. These projects rely on the NSF C-130 aircrafts for support as well as stop-overs of smaller aircraft at Summit for fueling.

 

All of these myriad of activities and utilization of resources creates a complicated and challenging requirements matrix that must be worked out each field season to deliver optimal scientific results. The SCO works closely with the NSF project managers and contractors to facilitate the optimal use of resources toward improved scientific deliveries. To accomplish this, the SCO conducts weekly tele-conference calls, semi-monthly tele-conference calls with the NSF contractors, and monthly calls with NSF program managers. A website (www.geosummit.org) is developed with updated information about what science is being conducted, links to available data archives, and updates specifically regarding the Long-Range Planning (LRP). This last point is perhaps the most critical of the SCO. Given the dynamic nature of funding and scientific demands for the facility, it is important to have a flexible planning horizon for the station. While the SCO attempts to develop a "Vision" for the facility, it is challenged frequently due to unforseen developments, and must be regularly revisited. The SCO strives to deliver a "Vision" that is representative of the demands and interest of the scientific community first and foremost with reverence to the realities and constraints placed on the development process due to funding and logistical constraints that come naturally with working on top of the Greenland Ice Sheet.
